title: Göteborgs-Posten
text:
Göteborgs-Posten (lit. "The Gothenburg Post"), abbreviated GP, is a major <a href="Swedish%20language">Swedish language</a> daily <a href="newspaper">newspaper</a> published in <a href="Gothenburg">Gothenburg</a>, <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a>.
History and profile.
"Göteborgs-Posten" was first published in 1813, but ceased publication in 1822. It re-appeared in 1850. Publication seven days a week began in 1939. The paper is owned and published by a family company, Stampen, a subsidiary of Hjörne group. It changed its format from the classic <a href="broadsheet">broadsheet</a> to <a href="compact%20%28newspaper%29">compact</a> on 5 October 2004.
"Göteborgs-Posten" is published in Gothenburg, with containing coverage of local, regional, national and international issues. It is chiefly distributed in western <a href="G%C3%B6taland">Götaland</a>. The stated position of the editorial page is <a href="Liberalism%20and%20centrism%20in%20Sweden">liberal</a> (which <a href="Liberalism%20and%20centrism%20in%20Sweden">in Sweden means center-right</a>).
Circulation.
According to its publisher, seven out of ten Gothenburgers read "Göteborgs-Posten" every day. In 1998 the circulation of the paper was 258,000 copies on weekdays and 286,000 copies on Sundays. The paper had a circulation of 245,900 copies on weekdays in 2005. It reached about 600,000 people every day with a circulation of 245,700 in 2006. Its 2010 circulation was 227,200 copies. The paper had a circulation of 189,400 copies in 2012 and 173,700 copies in 2013.
